persona.name: Nova Mei Holmgren

occupation.title: Frontend Software Engineer (Junior / Mid-level)
occupation.description: Works primarily on front-end features for a commuter-friendly transit and local services app. Responsibilities include implementing user interfaces in React Native and React, debugging, writing unit tests, collaborating with designers and QA, and mentoring interns/contractors occasionally. Has a hybrid schedule (3 days office, 2 days remote) to balance childcare. Regularly uses JavaScript/TypeScript, React, CSS-in-JS, Git, and Firebase. Participates in sprint planning, code reviews, and on-call rotations every few months. Also streams gaming content twice weekly in the evenings to a small but engaged audience; manages a brand account for clips and community interaction. Income: household combined approximately $68,000–72,000/year, within the specified $50,000–99,999 bracket.

persona.residence: Capitol Hill, Seattle, WA, USA (urban apartment renter)
persona.education: Associate of Applied Science in Web & Mobile Development from Seattle Central College (some college / associate degree). Several continuing-education certificates (React, UX fundamentals) completed through online platforms and employer-sponsored training.
long_term_goals: Provide a stable, nurturing upbringing and educational opportunities for her children so they can choose their own paths.
Buy a modest house within 10 years in a family-friendly neighborhood while maintaining the flexibility of her tech career.
Grow into a senior software engineer role or engineering lead while keeping at least two days/week remote to balance family life.
Build a small, reliable streaming/community brand around family-friendly gaming and tech content that supplements household income.
Establish lasting traditions that celebrate both halves of her blended heritage (Scandinavian and East Asian) and pass bilingual basics to her children.
Achieve enough financial stability to take a two-week family trip abroad every 3-4 years and frequent short regional vacations.
Maintain close friendships and community ties in the city, including involvement in a local parents' playgroup and volunteer opportunities at the neighborhood library.

style.general_description: Warm, energetic, digitally fluent urban millennial with casual, slightly eclectic style. Comfortable toggling between professional clarity at work and playful, informal voice online and with friends.
style.speech_and_tone: Speaks with a Pacific Northwest American accent with soft consonants. Uses colloquial, chatty register when with friends and online; switches to concise, plain-professional language in meetings and code reviews. Frequently peppers speech with tech shorthand ("LGTM," "PR," "deploy") and gaming slang ("GG," "nerf"). Uses emojis liberally in texts and social posts — hearts, baby emojis, controller icons — but keeps workplace communications emoji-free except occasional Slack reactions.
style.mannerisms: Laughs easily; smiles with a slight head tilt. Tends to tuck hair behind her ear when thinking. Uses hands while explaining technical or parenting points. Has a habit of fidgeting with a silicone baby-proofing strip or a small fidget ring while on calls. When excited about a game or a parenting win, her speech speeds up and she double-checks details aloud.
style.formality_and_register: Prefers informal, friendly register in most contexts, but respects structure in professional settings (agendas, PR descriptions). In parenting contexts she becomes more measured, descriptive, and reassuring.
style.online_persona: A genuine micro-influencer vibe: candid about parenting realities, posts short clips of kid-friendly gaming, easy recipes, and apartment hacks. Uses bright, slightly saturated photo filters, straightforward captions, and Q&A story stickers. Responds personally to many comments and DMs, leading to a small but loyal community.
style.physical_presentation: Comfort-first urban mom wardrobe: relaxed denim, breathable knits, sneakers for quick stroller runs, simple jewelry (small hoop earrings), and a practical crossbody bag or backpack. On weekends she swaps in older band tees and cropped jackets for social nights.
style.communication_preferences: Prefers asynchronous communication for non-urgent topics (Slack, email), quick texts for urgent family logistics. Likes shared Google Calendars for family scheduling. Appreciates visual explanations (screenshots, short video demos) over long written instructions.

traits: Affectionate and protective: warm toward close family, quick to defend her kids' needs.
Curious and learner-oriented: enjoys learning new frameworks, game mechanics, and parenting methods.
Resilient but occasionally anxious: handles daily stresses well but has worry spikes around finances and child health.
Playful and imaginative: brings games and stories into everyday parenting; invents mini-games for chores.
Sociable and network-oriented: values a small group of close friends and enjoys new parent meetups and local nightlife occasionally.
Pragmatic and resourceful: finds budget-friendly solutions (thrift, coupons, free events) and hacks life as a renter with kids.
Perfectionist about some things: meticulous about code quality and children's safety gear, but pragmatic elsewhere.
Emotionally open: shares feelings with close friends and online community, uses humor to diffuse tension.
Competitive in friendly ways: with games and fitness classes; dislikes unfairness.
Adaptable: switches plans easily when kids need change; comfortable with urban transit and babysitter swaps.
Values independence: pushes for her children's autonomy in safe ways and seeks personal time.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness high due to creative hobbies, bilingual curiosity, and experimentation with parenting. Conscientiousness high in work and child safety but flexible in household chores. Extraversion moderate — enjoys social outings but needs solo recharges. Agreeableness high: cooperative and caring, though will assert boundaries. Neuroticism moderate-low: generally stable with occasional anxiety episodes related to money and sleep deprivation.

interests: Video gaming (console and PC): platformers, co-op indie games, family-friendly titles, occasional competitive shooters with friends.
Technology and gadget tinkering: testing kid-safe tech like GPS watches and video monitors.
Content creation: short-form streaming clips, community chat, editing highlight reels.
Parenting communities: local parents' groups, online subreddits and Discord servers for tips and swap meets.
Music: synth-pop, indie folk playlists for chill evenings, upbeat playlists for playtime.
Food: quick weekday dinners, experimenting with simple Asian-Scandinavian fusion recipes.
Nightlife: occasional date nights and live music; prefers early-evening shows that end by 10:30 PM.
City culture: farmers' markets, pop-up street festivals, library storytime events.
Fitness: stroller walks, short HIIT sessions at home, weekend yoga classes.
DIY and apartment hacks: baby-proofing, clever storage, thrifted decor refreshes.
gaming_preferences: Plays primarily on Nintendo Switch and a mid-range gaming PC.
Favorite family games: Mario Kart, Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley for gentle co-play.
Favorite solo/streaming titles: indie platformers (Celeste, Hollow Knight), cozy sims, occasional Among Us with friends.
Dislikes toxic multiplayer environments; mutes and leaves quickly.
Streams 2 weeknights per week after the kids’ bedtime (usually 8:30–10:30 PM).
Uses a modest webcam and a compact mic; overlays show a small corner feed and chat.
Prefers games with clear tutorials and forgiving difficulty when including kids.
Collects in-game cosmetic items and supports indie devs via Kickstarter/backer tiers.
Enjoys watching speedruns and community co-op streams.
Encourages early-age exposure to simple cooperative gameplay with parental guidance.
coffee_and_cafe_preferences: Prefers medium roast lattes with oat milk as a default.
Enjoys iced coffee in summer; black drip for early morning boosts when working from home.
Favorite chain for convenience: local Seattle roastery over big national chains; knows baristas by name at neighborhood cafe.
Likes cafes with toddler-friendly corners (soft play mat or small book shelf).
Brings a reusable cup and prefers eco-friendly cafes.
Often uses cafes for weekend laptop work sessions during late mornings.
Snacks with coffee: banana bread or savory scone.
Dislikes overly cramped cafe spaces with no room for a stroller.
Prefers ambient music (low-volume indie or jazz) over loud pop.
Values reliable Wi-Fi and power outlets for quick work stretches.
nightlife_and_social_preferences: Enjoys casual meetups at a friend's apartment or a low-key bar with board games.
Helps organize monthly parents' social outings where kids are welcome earlier in the evening.
Prefers events that end before midnight due to childcare and early mornings.
Chooses venues with safe walking routes or short rideshare distances home.
Likes live indie music and small venue shows, rarely attends big late-night clubs.
Often coordinates babysitter swaps with another couple for a date night.
Avoids overly smoky venues and places with hostile service staff.
Likes a predictable routine: dinner, show, short walk, home by 11:00 PM.
food_and_meal_preferences: Meal prep fan: batch-cooks staples like rice bowls, soups, and muffin-sized egg cups for quick breakfasts.
Family favorites: miso-glazed salmon, Scandinavian rye pancakes adapted for toddlers, rice porridge with fruit.
Kid-friendly snacks: sliced apples with peanut butter, steamed veggie sticks, yogurt tubes.
Dining out: seeks restaurants with changing tables and children's menu options.
Picky-eater strategies: offers new foods alongside familiar favorites and never forces a bite.
Dislikes long, expensive fine-dining outings that are logistically difficult with kids.
Open to trying new cuisines but prefers places with clear ingredient descriptions due to allergies in extended family.
parenting_preferences_and_vacations: Vacation style: short trips (3–5 days) every 3–6 months and one longer family trip (7–14 days) every few years depending on budget and child's age.
Prefers destinations with family infrastructure: public transit, easy access to medical care, playgrounds, nearby grocery stores, and child-friendly attractions.
Likes a mix of structured activities (aquarium, zoo, children's museum) and relaxed downtime so children can nap and play.
Avoids overly scheduled tours; values flexibility around nap and meal times.
Seeks accommodations with separate sleeping areas for kids (suite or two-bedroom rentals) and kitchen/prep area for formula/baby food.
Brings a compact travel stroller, a travel crib, a white-noise machine app or portable machine, and a small first-aid kit.
Uses baby monitors and portable outlet covers when staying in rentals.
Prefers direct flights under 4 hours with early morning departure times for smoother kid transitions.
Chooses resorts or hotels that have family pools with lifeguards and shallow areas for toddlers.
Values playground access and safe, enclosed play areas at destinations.
Often plans a local 'babymoon' style weekend with spouse for recharging once or twice a year, using babysitter or grandparents.
When traveling with friends, organizes group childcare rotations so adults can have evening time.
Budget-conscious: prefers off-peak travel, uses credit-card points, and opts for Airbnb or family suites for kitchen access.
Dislikes travel experiences where child safety cannot be reasonably assured (e.g., remote hikes with no facilities when toddlers are present).
Carries kid entertainment kits: sticker books, small puzzles, single-device loaded with offline content, familiar blanket or stuffed toy.
Prefers travel rhythms that keep the children's routines as normal as possible (similar meal and nap times).
Open to traveling internationally when children are over 2.5 and vaccinated as appropriate, and when accommodations are kid-friendly.
Looks for playground exchanges and community-based childcare options in destination cities: library story hours, soft play centers.
Likes vacation itineraries that allow the spouse and herself brief solo time to recharge while children are supervised.
Avoids long overnight bus/train rides that disrupt sleep schedules for young children.
Enjoys combining family visits to relatives with short local day trips to keep costs down.
Prioritizes travel health insurance coverage and local pediatrician contacts in destination planning.
Believes vacations are more about family bonding than checking off attractions; tends to capture many candid photos and keep a simple travel journal.
media_and_content_preferences: Follows parenting blogs and Discord parenting servers for swap and support.
Watches a mix of streaming TV: light comedies, documentaries on education, and gaming streams.
Listens to parenting and technology podcasts while cooking or commuting.
Reads game design threads and UX newsletters to keep skills current.
Prefers short-form video tips (1–3 minutes) for parenting hacks, longer 15–30 minute deep dives for tech learning.
Avoids sensationalist news sources; prefers local reporting for community issues.
dislikes: Overly toxic online communities and anonymous trolling.
Rigid parenting dogma; prefers flexible, evidence-informed methods.
Crowds and long lines when handling children’s needs.
Overly expensive childcare options with poor communication.
Places without basic baby infrastructure (changing tables, safe play spaces).
Unreliable transit or unsafe walking routes near home.
Being judged for streaming games as a parent.

beliefs: Family should be a safe emotional and logistical support system for children.
Both parents should participate actively in childcare and household tasks; gender roles should be flexible.
Play-based early childhood learning is crucial for social and emotional development.
Vaccinations are important for public health; consult pediatrician for details.
Public transit and walkable neighborhoods improve quality of family life in cities.
Affordable, flexible childcare is key to working parents' wellbeing.
Technology is a tool — valuable for learning and work when used intentionally and supervised with kids.
Screen time should be limited for young children but used selectively for educational and co-play activities.
Parents should model digital civility and consent for privacy with kids from an early age.
Renting provides flexibility early in life, and home ownership is a goal but not the only path to stability.
A multicultural home enriches children’s identity and empathy; bilingual basics are worth teaching.
Community connections (neighbors, playgroups) reduce isolation and strengthen support networks.
Financial planning and modest emergency savings reduce family stress; consumerism should be balanced with savings goals.
Mental health is as important as physical health; therapy and peer support are valid resources.
Workplaces should offer realistic parental leave and flexible schedules for the benefit of employees and families.
Small, meaningful traditions (holiday food, bedtime rituals) create lasting memories.
Local parks, libraries, and free events are invaluable resources for young families on a budget.
Gender identity and expression should be supported and explored as children grow, without pushing identities prematurely.
Healthcare access and a pediatrician who listens are worth commuting for.
Voting matters in elections that affect schools, transit, and housing; participates intermittently, prioritizes local issues when possible.
Sustainability matters but should be practical: reusing, buying secondhand, and reducing waste where feasible.
Safety gear (car seats, helmets, pool barriers) is non-negotiable and should meet current standards.
Breastfeeding is valuable when it works for the family, but feeding choices are personal and deserve support.
Parental guilt is common and usually counterproductive; small consistent actions matter more than perfection.
Friends and date nights matter; couples need time together to sustain the relationship.
Diversity enriches schools and communities; seeks inclusive spaces for her children.
Employers’ transparency about pay and parental policy is a deciding factor when evaluating jobs.
Open conversations about money help partners align priorities and reduce stress.
Emergencies happen; having a list of local contacts, neighborhood parents, and backup childcare is sensible.
Honest, calm communication with children fosters trust more than punitive discipline.
Early exposure to music, books, and social play supports language and empathy.
Data privacy concerns are real; careful about children's images online and uses platform privacy settings.
There is value in sharing realistic parenting content; it helps break isolation and lowers stigma.
Not all advice applies universally; trusts a blend of evidence-based recommendations and lived experience.
Community childcare cooperatives can be a creative, affordable alternative to formal daycare.
Learning to say no — to extra commitments or pressure — is an important self-care skill for parents.
Affordable housing policy and safe neighborhoods are community priorities that influence family wellbeing.
skills: Frontend development: solid competencies in JavaScript, TypeScript, React, React Native, CSS-in-JS, responsive layouts, and component-driven design.
Basic backend familiarity: experience integrating Firebase and REST APIs and understanding auth flows.
Practical UX sensibility: able to rapidly prototype clickable mocks and translate designer feedback into code.
Debugging and testing: uses unit tests (Jest) and basic end-to-end checks, familiar with Chrome DevTools.
Content creation: recording, basic streaming setup, OBS, clip editing in DaVinci Resolve or similar, thumbnail creation.
Community building: engages viewers, responds to comments, moderates chat, organizes small community events.
Project collaboration: sprint planning, Git workflow, code reviews, and basic mentorship for interns.
Time management: compartments work sprints with childcare windows; uses Pomodoro and shared calendars.
Parenting skills: infant soothing, sleep association techniques, baby-first-aid and CPR certified within past 2 years.
Household management: budgeting, meal prep, apartment baby-proofing, efficient packing for travel.
Cooking: quick, balanced meals and adapting family recipes to toddler preferences.
Language skills: native English, basic Mandarin phrases taught by grandparents, some Swedish cultural phrases from spouse's side.
Negotiation and advocacy: communicates with daycare, landlords, and employers effectively to secure needed accommodations.
Crisis response: remains calm during minor medical events and coordinates care quickly.
Public speaking: comfortable doing short presentations internally at work and live-stream commentary to an audience.

general: Checks baby monitors and responds quickly to awakenings at night.
Posts a daily photo or short clip on social channels documenting a parenting win or a game highlight.
Keeps at least one weekend day for family outings to parks, library story times, or farmers' markets.
Uses transit and rideshares rather than relying on a personal car; borrows car from spouse for longer trips.
Schedules household chores into 20–40 minute blocks during kids' naps.
Leans on a network of neighborhood parents for gear swaps, babysitting swaps, and recommendations.
Sets firm screen-time boundaries for children and models moderate, mindful use of devices.
Maintains a small 'go bag' with diapers, snacks, a change of clothes, and a compact toy for quick outings.
Reviews streaming clips and chat logs to maintain community standards and learn content preferences.
Advocates politely but firmly for accommodations at work when childcare conflicts arise.

morning: 6:30 AM: Wakes if not earlier; checks overnight feed logs and baby monitor.
6:45–7:30 AM: Prepares oatmeal or egg muffins, brews coffee (oat latte), wakes older toddler with a song and cuddle.
7:30–8:15 AM: Gets kids dressed, packs daycare bag (with lunch and snack), checks calendar for that day’s logistics.
8:15–9:00 AM: Drop-off at nearby daycare; quick commute to office or starts work-from-home sprint if remote day.
workday: 9:00–12:00 PM: Focused coding blocks, daily standups, short feedback loops with designer.
12:00–1:00 PM: Lunch; occasionally a short walk or a call with her spouse to coordinate evening plans.
1:00–4:00 PM: Meetings, code reviews, implementation; fits in a 20-minute pump session or check-in with daycare if needed.
4:00–5:30 PM: Wraps work, documents progress, coordinates hand-off if on-call later.
5:30–7:00 PM: Pick up kids, prepare dinner, family playtime and bath routine.
evening: 7:00–8:30 PM: Bedtime routine for kids: story, lullaby, lights dim; older toddler has quiet play before bed.
8:30–10:30 PM: For streaming nights, sets up equipment, interacts with community while spouse handles baby monitor; other nights decompress with spouse, light TV, or editing clips.
10:30–11:30 PM: Finishes minor household tasks, preps for next day, checks messages, then to bed.
weekend: Saturday morning: family-led park visit or neighborhood farmers' market.
Saturday afternoon: laundry, errands, and community playdates or class (music-for-tots).
Sunday: relaxed morning, longer video call with family (grandparents), schedule planning for the week, and a date-in evenings if possible (babysitter or grandparents).

health.physical: Generally good health; regular gynecology and pediatric appointments up to date. Mild seasonal allergies (pollen) managed with OTC antihistamines. Slight myopia corrected with contacts and occasional glasses. Postpartum body healing completed after last pregnancy; experiences occasional low back stiffness from lifting, alleviated by weekly stretches and yoga.
health.mental: Overall stable mood with normal parenting-related stress. Had a brief period of postpartum anxiety after first child, treated with therapy (CBT techniques) and peer-support groups; no current diagnosis requiring medication. Practices mindfulness and uses short breathing exercises when overwhelmed.
health.immunizations_and_prevention: Up to date on routine adult immunizations; follows pediatric vaccination schedule for children. Keeps an emergency first-aid kit and is certified in infant/child CPR.
health.medical_history: No chronic illnesses. No major surgeries. No substance abuse. Occasional migraines related to late nights and screen time, managed by limiting screen exposure and taking OTC ibuprofen.
health.sleep: Fragmented sleep due to childcare needs but generally functional. Uses naps strategically during weekends when possible.
health.notes: Avoids new medications without consulting a physician; proactive about dental and vision care.

relationships.name: Liam Holmgren
relationships.description: Married partner; Scandinavian-American background, works as a barista-turned-retail manager with flexible hours. Shares childcare duties; enjoys weekend DIY projects and is the family's primary cook on some weekends. Supportive but occasionally anxious about finances. Shares parental responsibilities, babysitter network, and co-manages household finances. They met at a local indie concert venue and married two years ago in a small city ceremony blending both families' traditions.

relationships.name: Kai Holmgren
relationships.description: Energetic toddler, curious about cause-and-effect, loves blocks and chasing pigeons. Attends neighborhood daycare three days a week. Early talker with a growing vocabulary. Sleeps through most nights but has occasional separation anxiety.

relationships.name: Aria Holmgren
relationships.description: Note: This entry conflicts with requirement that children are less than 6. To follow primary specification, Aria is actually 1 year old. Aria (1) is a mellow infant who enjoys music and snuggling, naps reliably in the afternoon, and prefers tactile toys. (Correction: Aria is 1.)

Grandparents on both sides are involved: maternal grandmother is bilingual and sends occasional care packages with cultural foods; paternal aunt visits a few times a year and provides childcare backup. Family lives across the region, enabling periodic visits but not daily help.

A small circle of 4–6 close friends from college and local parenting groups who trade babysitting duties, swap gear, and meet weekly for coffee or park playdates. One friend is a fellow developer who often pairs on coding problems and babysitting swaps.
Colleagues at MetroApps, a mentor from an online bootcamp, and a small streaming community that functions as social support and occasional side-income collaborators.

other_facts: Full name reflects blended heritage: 'Mei' honors her Chinese maternal grandmother; 'Holmgren' is her spouse's family name of Swedish origin, which she adopted after marriage.
Born and raised in the suburbs of Seattle; moved to Capitol Hill for proximity to transit, friends, and family-friendly resources.
Bicultural household: grandparents on maternal side call the children by Mandarin nicknames; Liam's family contributes Scandinavian recipes and holiday traditions.
Speaks basic Mandarin phrases taught by her mother and grandmother; uses them selectively with her children (counting, simple greetings).
Favorite childhood memory: a summer carnival where she won a stuffed tiger that still sits on a shelf as a sentimental object.
First computer at age 12 sparked an interest in web design; built small fan sites in high school.
Attended community college while working part-time at a café; credits that period with teaching time management and budgeting skills.
Got into gaming via a childhood neighbor who shared their Nintendo; remembers learning to share controllers and trade game tips.
Started streaming casually after co-workers encouraged her to clip funny co-op moments; built a small community of parents who game.
Her wedding combined a simple courthouse civil ceremony and a potluck reception with both families contributing dishes: miso soup and Finnish meatballs among them.
Had an emergency C-section with first child; recovery involved support from spouse and community lactation consultants.
Has a recurring anxiety about housing affordability in Seattle; actively tracks rental listings and mortgage programs for first-time buyers.
Maintains an emergency envelope with a list of pediatrician numbers, insurance cards, a small cash reserve, and photocopies of important documents.
Was the first in her immediate family to attend college-level tech training and feels a responsibility to model continuing education for friends.
Enjoys small rituals: a Friday-night 'family pizza and game' session where everyone participates in silly roles.
Owns a well-worn stuffed whale from childhood that she uses as a comfort object and sometimes as a prop during storytime.
Keeps an illustrated travel journal (photos and short notes) for family trips; uses it later as a bedtime book to share memories with kids.
Has an ongoing side-project: a small site documenting affordable kid-friendly spots in Seattle with user-contributed tips.
Has a small credit-card debt from laptop upgrades and household expenses but pays consistently; building an emergency fund slowly.
Saves via automatic transfers to a joint account earmarked for housing downpayment and another for kids’ activities.
Is a member of the neighborhood library and volunteers occasionally for weekend story hours when schedule permits.
Once helped organize a small neighborhood playground cleanup and got city parks department to replace a broken swing.
Is careful about what kid photos she posts online: avoids full-name captions and geotagging; uses private accounts for close friends.
Has a mild fear of deep water for herself; enforces pool safety strictly for kids and takes infant swim-safety classes.
Values thrift shopping and upcycles kids' clothes; organizes gear swaps among parent friends regularly.
Has a habit of saving tiny ticket stubs, a postcard, or a pressed leaf from every family trip in a memory box.
Admires certain engineers publicly (writes small thank-you notes on Twitter-style platforms for inspiring tutorials) and occasionally reaches out for mentorship advice.
Enjoys a playful annual tradition where she and spouse remake one dish from their childhoods and talk about family memories over it.
Is allergic to nothing severe; carries an antihistamine for seasonal hay fever and keeps an EpiPen in the household because a friend has a severe allergy and they sometimes host dinners.
Owns a small rubber duck collection used as bath-time props to make baths fun for the kids.
Uses a shared Google Keep list with spouse for grocery and household items; it acts as a living household command center.
Was briefly an administrator of a local parenting Facebook group, where she moderated posts and organized a school supply drive.
Knits occasionally when stressed; simple baby hat patterns are her usual go-to.
Has a favorite park bench at a nearby park where she brings a thermos on slow workdays and reflects on parenting choices.
Keeps a rotating 'comfort playlist' for late-night nursing or rocking sessions; includes both Mandarin lullabies from grandmother and soft Scandinavian folk tunes.
Had a close friend move away last year which prompted her to be more intentional about scheduling meetups and preserving friendships.
Is learning more about family-centered financial planning and recently attended a free workshop on saving for college alternatives and vocational paths.
Often imagines small business ideas combining tech and parenting (an app that helps parents swap shifts or trade babysitting hours) and keeps a private kanban board for side-project ideas.
Her streaming community once raised funds to buy new books for the daycare she uses; she helped coordinate the donation and felt proud of the collective effort.
Keeps a 'date night' ritual envelope that contains printed movie suggestions, conversation prompts, or coupons for babysitters — they draw one on random Saturdays to keep things fresh.
Collects a small set of children's picture books that reflect diverse family structures and languages; rotates them frequently to expose children to variety.
Was part of a workplace equity committee that advocated for clearer parental leave policies and more flexible hours; uses that experience to negotiate accommodations for herself and peers.
